title: Hotdog-Sandwich Consensus Framework

prerequisites: Identify and recruit diverse stakeholder representatives
steps.outcome: Establish legitimate taxonomic authority through inclusive deliberation
risks: Difficulty in getting buy-in from entrenched ideological camps
Potential for grandstanding and unproductive debate

prerequisites: Analyze structural, cultural, and culinary perspectives
steps.outcome: Create a hybrid classification that respects both structural and cultural dimensions
risks: Resistance to complexity over simple binary categorization
Challenges in establishing clear operational definitions

steps.action: Implement Flexible Labeling and Regulatory Standards
prerequisites: Engage with food service industry and regulatory bodies
Pilot test classification system with consumers
steps.outcome: Establish practical guidelines that accommodate diverse perspectives
risks: Pushback from stakeholders over perceived compromises
Difficulty in achieving consistent application across contexts

steps.action: Launch Public Education and Conflict Resolution Initiatives
prerequisites: Develop compelling narratives to explain the new classification framework
Establish mediation channels for resolving disputes
steps.outcome: Foster societal understanding and acceptance of the dual-taxonomy approach
risks: Entrenched ideological positions resistant to new information
Potential for the issue to become a proxy for broader cultural divides

steps.action: Continuously Evaluate and Iterate the Framework
prerequisites: Collect feedback from stakeholders and the public
Monitor emerging trends and taxonomic developments
steps.outcome: Maintain the relevance and legitimacy of the classification system over time
risks: Difficulty in balancing stability and flexibility
Potential for new controversies to arise around edge cases

resource_requirements: Funding for the Hotdog-Sandwich Classification Commission
Expertise in food science, linguistics, and conflict resolution
Engagement and buy-in from key stakeholder groups
